hypotheses.source_question: How do complex structure moduli constraints on the Calabi-Yau manifold couple to or constrain the Kähler moduli space, and what is the precise directionality and mechanism of this coupling in determining the effective string landscape geometry?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that complex structure moduli deformations causally constrain the Kähler moduli space through a hierarchical back-reaction mechanism in which the superpotential curvature (second derivatives of W with respect to complex structure) directly determines the metric curvature of the Kähler moduli subspace, reducing the effective dimensionality and range of Kähler deformations available to stabilization.
hypotheses.mechanism: Complex structure moduli enter the type IIB superpotential W as polynomial terms. Deformations in complex structure change the local curvature ∂²W/∂z_i∂z_j, which through the mirror map and Picard–Fuchs equations propagates to the periods Π of the mirror family. These periods determine the Kähler metric on moduli space via the special geometry relation. Thus, complex structure variations causally precede and constrain Kähler geometry: varying complex structure moduli non-trivially transforms the Hessian of the effective potential restricted to the Kähler directions, enforcing correlations between which Kähler moduli can be independently stabilized.
hypotheses.prediction: For a one-parameter family of Calabi-Yau manifolds with both complex structure (z) and Kähler (t) moduli, the ratio of the Hessian eigenvalue spread in the (t, t̄) sector before and after complex structure deformation will exceed 3:1, and the effective dimensionality (participation ratio) of the Kähler moduli subspace will decrease by at least 20% as complex structure is varied across 50% of its fundamental domain.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, after systematically deforming complex structure moduli across their full fundamental domain and recomputing the Kähler metric and effective potential Hessian, the ratio of Hessian eigenvalue spreads remains <1.5:1 and the participation ratio of Kähler moduli shows no systematic trend (monotonic or monotonic with statistical significance p<0.05), the hypothesis is refuted; or if the effective dimensionality of stabilizable Kähler moduli increases with complex structure deformation (opposite causal direction).
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Eigenvalue ratio of Kähler Hessian sector ≥ 1.5 (indicative of constraint), or explained variance in Kähler moduli correlation by complex structure deformation ≥ 15% (R² > 0.15); participation ratio drop ≥ 10% statistically significant at p < 0.05 with n ≥ 500 sampled moduli configurations.

experiment.approach: Construct explicit Calabi-Yau families (e.g., hypersurfaces in weighted projective spaces or Fermat families) with parameterized complex and Kähler deformations. Compute periods and mirror maps numerically. Systematically sample complex structure deformations, recompute the Kähler moduli metric and effective potential Hessian at each point, and measure the causal influence of complex structure changes on Kähler eigenvalue structure and stabilization constraints.
steps: Select a tractable Calabi-Yau family with explicit complex structure deformation space (e.g., degree-d hypersurface in ℂℙ⁴ with polynomial moduli, or Dwork family parameterized by ψ).
Compute the periods Ω_i(z, ψ) using Picard–Fuchs operators and Gauss hypergeometric functions for a grid of complex structure parameters z ∈ [0, z_max] (normalized fundamental domain).
Apply mirror symmetry: extract the mirror Kähler moduli space metric g_IJ = ∂²K/∂t_I∂t̄_J from the periods via special geometry (K = -ln(i(Π̄ · Π))).
For each complex structure value z_k, compute the Hessian H_IJ of the type IIB effective potential V_eff(t, z_k) with respect to Kähler moduli; extract eigenvalues λ_1(z_k), …, λ_h(z_k).
Quantify Hessian constraint: compute the ratio R(z_k) = λ_max(z_k) / λ_min(z_k) and the participation ratio PR(z_k) = (Σ_i λ_i)² / (Σ_i λ_i²) (measure of effective dimensionality).
Perform linear regression: fit R(z) and PR(z) as functions of complex structure parameter(s); extract slope and R² to measure coupling strength and explained variance.

For a random sample of 500 configurations in the (z, t) moduli space, compute pairwise correlations between complex structure motions and Kähler Hessian eigenvector shifts using CCA (Canonical Correlation Analysis).
Contrast with null: randomize complex structure deformations while holding Kähler metric fixed; measure eigenvalue spread and participation ratio statistics under the null hypothesis.

Generate a causal DAG (directed acyclic graph) using graphical Lasso or constraint-based causal discovery (PC/FCI algorithm) on the moduli parameter + Hessian eigenvalue dataset; test directionality z → t vs. t → z.
tools: GeoMod / Macaulay2 (Calabi-Yau family construction and deformation equations)
Sage / SymPy (period and Picard–Fuchs computation)
mpmath (arbitrary-precision hypergeometric function evaluation)
NumPy / SciPy (eigendecomposition, Hessian computation, linear regression)
scikit-learn (CCA, participation ratio calculation)
Causalnx / DoWhy (causal DAG inference and directionality testing)
Published mirror data (e.g., Kreuzer–Skarke database for Calabi-Yau examples)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–8 weeks of focused compute + analysis. Period computation and Hessian eigendecomposition scale as O(n_moduli³) per configuration; 500–1000 configurations × 100–1000 CPU hours total (parallelizable).
experiment.data_requirements: Explicit Calabi-Yau family with known mirror and period integrals (e.g., Dwork or Fermat quintic); access to high-precision special-geometry libraries or ability to implement Picard–Fuchs solvers; moduli space grids for 1–3 complex structure + 1–5 Kähler parameters.
experiment.expected_positive: Eigenvalue ratio R(z) shows monotonic dependence on complex structure z with R² > 0.15; participation ratio PR(z) decreases systematically (slope < −0.01 normalized) as z varies; CCA canonical correlation between z-motion and Kähler Hessian eigenvector shifts > 0.4; graphical Lasso causal graph infers z → t edges with Bayesian posterior > 0.7.
experiment.expected_negative: R(z) and PR(z) show no systematic trend (scatter consistent with white noise, R² < 0.05) or noise levels exceed signal; CCA correlation < 0.2; causal DAG is undirected or infers reverse direction t → z with higher posterior; eigenvalue spread ratio remains <1.5 across all z.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Complex structure deformations are conditionally independent of Kähler moduli geometry given the Calabi-Yau topological class (h^{1,1}, h^{1,2}). Changes in complex structure z produce no statistically significant (p > 0.05) correlation with or causal influence on Kähler Hessian eigenvalues or metric tensor elements.
experiment.statistical_test: Pearson correlation test (α = 0.05, two-tailed) for R(z) and PR(z) trends across ≥100 sampled z values; linear regression F-test for R² > 0.15 significance; non-parametric Mann–Whitney U-test to compare Hessian eigenvalue distributions under complex structure variation vs. randomized null; causal discovery PC/FCI algorithm with Fisher's z-test for conditional independence (α = 0.05).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Correlation coefficient r > 0.25 (moderate, detectable with n≥100 sampled configurations at 80% power); eigenvalue ratio shift ≥1.5× (corresponding to >33% decrease in effective Kähler dimension); R² in regression ≥ 0.15 (15% variance explained). For causal direction: posterior probability of z → t edge ≥ 0.7 in Bayesian DAG inference.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Assuming complex structure grid sampling n_z ≈ 100–200 configurations, each with Hessian eigendecomposition on h^{1,1} ∈ [2, 10], achieve 80% power to detect correlation r > 0.25 at α = 0.05. For CCA: n_configs = 500 (effective moduli space samples), expected canonical correlation under H₁ ≈ 0.5, design power > 0.90 at α = 0.05. Causal DAG inference requires n ≥ 300–500 to reliably distinguish z → t from t → z or independence.
limitations: Results are specific to the chosen Calabi-Yau family; generalization to the full landscape requires sampling multiple topological types (e.g., K3 × T², intersecting brane families).
Superpotential W is computed only for the closed string sector; open string (brane) moduli and their coupling to W are not included, limiting applicability to flux compactifications without branes.
Period computation is sensitive to branch cut choices and analytic continuation; finite-precision arithmetic may obscure fine structure in Hessian eigenvalue correlations.
Causal inference from observational data (moduli space sampling) cannot definitively prove causation; alternative confounders (e.g., common dependence on topological invariants) may exist.
Effective potential is evaluated at tree-level (no loop corrections or non-perturbative effects); quantum corrections could alter coupling strength.
experiment.requires_followup: Wet-lab analogue not applicable (string landscape is a mathematical/computational domain). Recommended follow-up: (1) Extend to explicit type IIB flux compactifications with numerical flux stabilization algorithms; (2) Validate causal mechanism by deriving explicit closed-form expressions for the back-reaction term in the Kähler metric as a function of complex structure via holomorphic anomaly equations; (3) Cross-validate findings on a second, topologically distinct Calabi-Yau family to test robustness; (4) Combine with geometric engineering to connect moduli coupling to gauge theory constraints.

hypotheses.source_question: Does the string landscape's distribution of effective low-energy gauge couplings naturally produce configurations in which gauge coupling unification occurs, and if so, what fraction of string vacua satisfy this condition as a fundamental prediction rather than an input constraint?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that gauge coupling unification emerges as a generic statistical attractor in the string landscape, with the fraction of string vacua exhibiting unified couplings (α₁ ≈ α₂ ≈ α₃ within 5% at a unification scale M_U > 10¹⁵ GeV) being at least 3–5 times higher than expected from random chance, and that this enrichment is causally driven by geometric constraints on Kähler moduli and flux quantization rather than anthropic selection.
hypotheses.mechanism: String compactifications constrain the running of low-energy gauge couplings through their effective Kähler potential and threshold corrections, which depend on Calabi-Yau geometry and flux choices. Vacua with specific topological properties (e.g., moderate Kähler cone volume, rational flux quantization) naturally produce RG trajectories that converge to unified couplings at high scales. This geometric mechanism causes unification to appear as a landscape attractor, independent of model-building assumptions, rather than requiring post-hoc tuning.
hypotheses.prediction: Scanning a representative subset of the string landscape (>10,000 distinct vacua from heterotic, Type IIA/IIB, or F-theory constructions with explicit low-energy spectra) will yield a unification fraction f_unif ≥ 0.05–0.08 (5–8%), compared to a null-hypothesis baseline of f_random ≈ 0.01–0.02 (1–2%) expected from random coupling combinations. Vacua satisfying unification will exhibit a mean Kähler modulus volume V_K and average flux quantization parameter Q_flux that differ statistically significantly (p < 0.01) from non-unifying vacua.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the fraction of unifying vacua in the scanned landscape is ≤ 0.015 (i.e., consistent with random chance at p > 0.05), or if unifying vacua show no statistically significant correlation (p > 0.10) with geometric/topological features (Kähler volume, flux quantization, Hodge numbers), the hypothesis is refuted. This would indicate that unification is either a rare accident or requires anthropic explanation rather than being a generic landscape feature.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Unification fraction f_unif ≥ 0.05 (at least 5-fold enrichment over random baseline of ~0.01); Pearson r ≥ 0.25 or Spearman ρ ≥ 0.25 between unification status and Kähler geometric invariants; p < 0.01 (two-sided) for enrichment test comparing unifying vs. non-unifying populations.

experiment.approach: Construct or retrieve an annotated database of string theory vacua with explicit low-energy spectra (gauge groups, matter multiplicities, threshold corrections). For each vacuum, compute the running of gauge couplings from M_EW to M_Planck using two-loop RGE and extract unification scale and precision. Classify vacua into unifying and non-unifying cohorts, then perform statistical and geometric correlation analysis.
steps: Retrieve or construct a census of ≥10,000 distinct string vacua from published heterotic, Type IIA/IIB, or F-theory constructions. Prioritize sources with fully specified gauge groups (e.g., standard model extensions), matter representations, and Yukawa couplings (e.g., CICY database, Kreuzer–Skarke data, or F-theory GUT constructions by Vafa, Weigand, or Weigl).

For each vacuum, extract: (i) low-energy gauge group and matter content; (ii) characteristic Kähler modulus volume V_K (from compactification geometry); (iii) flux quantization parameters (total flux, primitive flux); (iv) Hodge numbers h¹¹, h₁₂; (v) alpha-angles or other threshold correction proxies if available.

Compute the one-loop and two-loop running of the three Standard Model coupling constants (α₁, α₂, α₃) from M_EW = 91 GeV to M_Planck = 2.4 × 10¹⁸ GeV using established RGE coefficients for each gauge group. Use publicly available RGE solvers (e.g., SusyRGE, PyRGE, or custom implementation in Python/Mathematica).

For each vacuum, determine whether a unification scale M_U exists such that |α₁(M_U) – α₂(M_U)| < 0.05·α_GUT and |α₂(M_U) – α₃(M_U)| < 0.05·α_GUT at M_U ∈ [10¹⁵, 10¹⁸] GeV. Record unification scale, coupling values, and precision metric δ = max(|α_i – α_j|)/α_GUT.
Classify vacua into two cohorts: U (unifying, δ < 0.05) and N (non-unifying, δ ≥ 0.05). Compute unification fraction f_unif = |U|/(|U| + |N|).

Perform statistical tests: (i) Compute baseline f_random by Monte Carlo sampling of random gauge unification from flat distributions of coupling constants, repeated 10,000 times. (ii) Use two-proportion z-test to assess whether f_unif >> f_random (H₀: f_unif = f_random). (iii) For each geometric/topological feature (V_K, flux quantization, Hodge numbers), compute Pearson correlation r or Spearman ρ with unification status (binary indicator). (iv) Perform Mann–Whitney U tests to compare distributions of V_K, flux parameters, and topological invariants between U and N cohorts.

Perform secondary analysis: regress unification precision δ against geometric features using linear or logistic regression to identify the strongest geometric predictors of unification. Compute partial correlation coefficients to disentangle independent vs. confounded effects.
Generate visualization: scatter plots of Kähler volume vs. unification scale, stratified by unification status; histograms of δ and V_K for U vs. N; correlation heatmap of landscape observables.
tools: Kreuzer–Skarke Calabi-Yau database (or equivalent CICY census)
F-theory GUT vacuum data (Weigl, Vafa, or Weigand compilations if available)
PyRGE or SusyRGE for RGE computation; alternatively custom Python/Mathematica scripts using established beta-function coefficients
SciPy, NumPy, Pandas for statistical analysis and data manipulation
Matplotlib/Seaborn for visualization
Public string landscape repositories (e.g., string-theory archives, arXiv preprints with explicit vacuum data)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–8 weeks: 1 week data curation, 1 week RGE code development/validation, 2–3 weeks vacuum enumeration and coupling computation (parallelizable), 1–2 weeks statistical analysis and interpretation.
experiment.data_requirements: Annotated database of ≥10,000 string vacua with gauge groups, matter multiplicities, and geometric invariants (Kähler volume, flux quantization, Hodge numbers). Access to Kreuzer–Skarke or CICY databases and published F-theory GUT construction papers. Standard Model RGE parameters (PDG, established gauge coupling running).
experiment.expected_positive: Unification fraction f_unif ∈ [0.05, 0.12] with statistical significance p < 0.01 in two-proportion test. Unifying vacua exhibit mean V_K and flux quantization significantly different from non-unifying vacua (p < 0.01, Mann–Whitney U). Pearson r or Spearman ρ between unification status and geometric features ≥ 0.25. Logistic regression identifies Kähler volume and flux quantization as independent predictors of unification (β ≠ 0, p < 0.05 each). Interpretation: geometric constraints naturally favor unified couplings, supporting a landscape attractor mechanism.
experiment.expected_negative: Unification fraction f_unif ≤ 0.015 (consistent with random chance, p > 0.10 in two-proportion test). Unifying and non-unifying vacua show no significant differences in V_K, flux quantization, or Hodge numbers (all Mann–Whitney U, p > 0.10). Correlation between unification status and all geometric features: r, ρ < 0.10. Interpretation: unification does not emerge as a landscape attractor; GUT unification requires anthropic tuning or is a coincidence.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The fraction of string vacua exhibiting gauge coupling unification equals the baseline fraction expected from random coupling configurations (f_unif = f_random ≈ 0.01–0.02). Equivalently, unification status is statistically independent of vacuum geometry (Kähler volume, flux quantization, topological invariants).
experiment.statistical_test: Two-proportion z-test comparing f_unif (observed in landscape) vs. f_random (Monte Carlo baseline), α = 0.01 (one-tailed, testing f_unif > f_random). Secondary tests: Mann–Whitney U tests for geometric feature distributions (α = 0.01); Pearson/Spearman correlation tests for unification–geometry associations (α = 0.05, two-tailed, Bonferroni correction if multiple comparisons). Logistic regression with unification as binary outcome and geometric features as predictors; report p-values and 95% confidence intervals for coefficients.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Two-proportion test: assume f_random ≈ 0.015, desired power 0.90, α = 0.01 (one-tailed); n = 10,000 vacua detects f_unif ≥ 0.035 (i.e., ≥2.3-fold enrichment). Correlation: Pearson r ≥ 0.25 detectable with n = 10,000 at power 0.99 and α = 0.05. Mann–Whitney U: effect size (Cliff's delta) ≥ 0.15 detectable at power 0.90, α = 0.01 with n = 5,000 per group.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Sample size n = 10,000 vacua is chosen to: (i) provide ≥90% power to detect f_unif ≥ 0.035 (2.3-fold enrichment over f_random ≈ 0.015) at α = 0.01 (one-tailed), assuming binomial test; (ii) achieve >0.95 power for Pearson r ≥ 0.25 (moderate effect) at α = 0.05; (iii) provide robust subgroup analysis (e.g., stratification by compactification type, gauge group size). For RGE convergence in computational loops: set absolute tolerance 10⁻⁶ relative to α_GUT to ensure numerical precision. Parallel computation on multi-core cluster recommended (estimated ≥10⁸ RGE evaluations at ~10 ms/evaluation = ~1,000 CPU-hours total).
limitations: Database completeness: published string vacuum compilations are biased toward certain construction methods (e.g., F-theory GUTs) and may not represent the true landscape distribution uniformly. Mitigation: stratify analysis by construction type and perform sensitivity analysis excluding largest/smallest subsets.

RGE validity: two-loop RGE is reliable up to ~M_Planck but assumes unbroken gauge group throughout; actual threshold corrections at intermediate scales (e.g., from moduli stabilization) are not captured. Mitigation: include published threshold correction estimates where available; test robustness by varying thresholds ±10%.

Unification criterion choice: threshold δ < 0.05 is somewhat arbitrary. Mitigation: perform sensitivity analysis with alternative thresholds (0.03, 0.07, 0.10); report results for each and discuss robustness.

Confounding by gauge group: different gauge groups naturally have different RGE trajectories. Unification enrichment may reflect correlation with gauge group structure rather than geometry. Mitigation: perform regression analyses controlling for gauge group size/type; stratify by gauge group family (SU(5), SO(10), etc.) and repeat tests within strata.

Limited low-energy spectrum data: many landscape vacua lack fully specified Yukawa couplings or threshold corrections. This forces use of generic RGE coefficients. Mitigation: restrict primary analysis to vacua with explicit spectra (e.g., CICY, heterotic constructions); repeat with approximate coefficients as robustness check.

Lack of independent replication dataset: string landscape data are scattered across papers; no single reproducible repository exists. Different authors use different conventions (e.g., coupling normalization). Mitigation: cross-validate RGE computations against published results (e.g., MSSM unification scale); use standardized coupling definitions (canonical GUT normalization).
experiment.requires_followup: None required for primary computational result. However, to fully validate mechanism (geometric causality), a follow-up wet-lab / observational step would be to: (i) construct explicit heterotic or F-theory models within the high-unification-fraction subset of the landscape and verify their renormalizability and coupling running against RGE predictions; (ii) measure / constrain landscape statistics observationally (e.g., via CMB data, collider phenomenology) if unification fraction is high, to test whether anthropic/observational selection aligns with predicted frequencies. This is beyond the scope of the primary computational experiment.

hypotheses.source_question: What are the precise conditions under which Type IIA and Type IIB string theories emerge as dual descriptions of a single underlying physical reality, and can these duality conditions be characterized in terms of geometric or topological invariants that predict when T-duality vs. mirror symmetry applies?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that T-duality and mirror symmetry act as commuting elements of a single unified duality group whose algebraic structure is fully determined by the homology lattice of the underlying Calabi–Yau manifold, and that this group structure causally determines which Type IIA and Type IIB vacua are physically equivalent.
hypotheses.mechanism: T-duality permutes Type IIA and IIB via exchange of odd/even-dimensional cycles on the dual torus fiber, while mirror symmetry exchanges Kähler and complex moduli. We propose these operations generate a finite-index subgroup of the geometric automorphism group of the moduli space. The causal direction flows from the homological structure of the Calabi–Yau → duality group generators → equivalence classes of Type II vacua. Commutation of generators implies that moduli-space orbits under the duality group are path-independent, predicting unique vacuum equivalences.
hypotheses.prediction: For a given family of Calabi–Yau threefolds with toric or K3-fibered structure, the fraction of apparently distinct Type IIA and Type IIB flux vacua that can be mapped to each other by explicit duality transformations (represented as elements of a presentation of the duality group) will exceed 70% when orbits are computed using the homology-lattice-derived group generators, compared to <20% matching rate if duality transformations are applied randomly or without group structure.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, for a computationally tractable family of Calabi–Yau compactifications (e.g., K3×K3 products or complete intersections in weighted projective space), the explicit duality group derived from homological data maps fewer than 50% of Type IIA vacua to Type IIB vacua (or vice versa), and this fraction is statistically indistinguishable from random pairing (null model ~20%), then the hypothesis is falsified: the duality group does not fully capture equivalences.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Orbit-matching fraction ≥70% (vs. random null baseline ~20%); statistical significance χ² > 10 (p < 0.01) when comparing observed orbit sizes to null distribution; Jaccard similarity of duality-predicted and numerically-identified equivalence classes ≥0.65.

experiment.approach: Develop a computational pipeline that (1) constructs explicit homology lattices for families of Calabi–Yau threefolds, (2) derives the duality group presentation from lattice automorphisms and mirror involutions, (3) enumerates Type II vacua in fixed flux sectors, and (4) tests whether duality-group elements map maximal-matching subsets of IIA solutions to IIB solutions. Validate against published flux-compactification databases.
steps: Select a tractable Calabi–Yau family: K3×K3, quartic K3-fibered threefolds, or complete intersections in ℙ⁴ with h¹¹ ≤ 100. Compute Hodge diamonds and homology lattice using existing tools (SageMath, Macaulay2, or CICY database).

Derive the geometric automorphism group and mirror involution σ: H¹¹(X) → H¹¹(X') explicitly. Generate a presentation of the duality group ⟨ T, S ⟩ where T is T-duality (acts on H_odd) and S is mirror symmetry (acts on H_even).

Parametrize Type II moduli spaces: for IIA, use Kähler moduli K_i, B-field flux components, and RR charges; for IIB, use complex moduli z_α and axio-dilaton τ. Set up a flux quantization constraint for a fixed tadpole cancellation number.

Enumerate representatives of Type II vacua in a small flux sector (e.g., ∑|G₄|² < 100 for IIB; equivalent for IIA) using sampling or exact enumeration. Extract low-energy observables: gauge coupling constants, scalar potential, 4D gravitino mass.

For each IIA vacuum, apply duality group elements (as matrices acting on moduli coordinates) to predict an equivalent IIB configuration. Compare predicted and actual moduli values (up to rounding error ~10⁻⁶).

Compute the orbit size distribution under the duality group action. Measure: (a) fraction of IIA vacua with ≥1 duality-related IIB partner, (b) mean orbit size, (c) proportion of low-energy observables that remain invariant under duality.
Test statistical significance: χ² goodness-of-fit between observed orbit-size distribution and null model (Poisson or uniform random pairing).
Cross-validate against CICY and Kreuzer–Skarke databases: check whether known Type IIA/IIB dual pairs are correctly predicted by the algorithmic duality group.
tools: SageMath or Macaulay2 (homology computation, lattice automorphisms)
CICY database (complete intersection Calabi–Yau)
Kreuzer–Skarke database (reflexive polytopes, mirror pairs)
Custom Python pipeline for flux enumeration and duality-group action
Computational Algebraic Geometry library (e.g., polymake) for polytope duality
Published flux-compactification datasets (e.g., from Denef–Douglas string cosmology papers)
experiment.estimated_effort: 4–8 weeks (develop homology and duality-group computation ~2 weeks; implement flux enumeration and orbit algorithm ~2 weeks; validation and statistical analysis ~2 weeks).
experiment.data_requirements: Hodge diamond and mirror involution data for Calabi–Yau families (available in CICY and Kreuzer–Skarke databases); published flux-compactification catalogues; computational resources for homology lattice computation (standard multi-core CPU, <100 GB disk).
experiment.expected_positive: For K3×K3 or another test family, ≥70% of Type IIA vacua (in a fixed flux sector) map to Type IIB vacua under explicit duality-group generators; statistical test χ² > 10 (p < 0.01); Jaccard similarity ≥0.65 between predicted and empirically-identified duality partners; low-energy observables (e.g., gauge couplings α_GUT, scalar potential V₀) show statistical invariance (variance <5% across duality orbit).
experiment.expected_negative: Fewer than 50% of Type IIA vacua are matched to Type IIB partners; orbit-size distribution is indistinguishable from random (χ² < 3, p > 0.2); Jaccard similarity <0.4; published IIA/IIB dual pairs in literature are not recovered by the predicted duality group.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The duality group structure is not fully captured by homological automorphisms and mirror symmetry alone. Type IIA and IIB vacua are not systematically equivalent under any fixed finite group action, or equivalences occur at a rate consistent with random matching (~20% for a typical vacua census).
experiment.statistical_test: χ² goodness-of-fit test comparing observed orbit-size histogram to null model (Poisson distribution or uniform random pairing). Two-sided test, α = 0.05. Supplementary: Jaccard similarity test (permutation test with 10,000 resamples to assess whether predicted orbit structure matches empirically identified dual partners).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Orbit-matching fraction ≥70% (vs. random null ~20%) is detectable with n=500 vacua and α=0.05, 80% power, under χ² test if true effect ≥50 percentage points. For smaller Calabi–Yau families (n≤100), a minimum detectable orbit-matching fraction of ≥60% (vs. null ~20%) at 80% power. Jaccard similarity ≥0.65 is clinically meaningful for duality-group recovery.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Assume 500 Type II vacua enumerated in a flux sector (achievable for K3×K3 with modest flux truncation). Under null (random matching at 20%), expect ~100 accidental matches; under alternative (duality-based 70%), expect ~350. Fisher's exact test or χ² with continuity correction: power ≈0.95 at α=0.05 for this sample size. For computational convergence: run orbit enumeration until duality group is generated to closure (verified by checking that all generator products are in the group), typically ≤1000 group multiplications for rank-12 lattices.
limitations: Computational tractability limits Calabi–Yau families to those with h¹¹ ≲ 100; some regions of the landscape (e.g., large-h¹¹ manifolds) may show different duality structure.
Flux quantization and tadpole constraints restrict the vacua census to finite sectors; global landscape statistics may differ.

Mirror symmetry is involutive (σ² = 1) by definition, but T-duality group structure may be more complex; the hypothesis assumes a simple presentation—non-obvious commutation relations could invalidate the simple group model.
Numerical precision in moduli-space coordinate matching: floating-point rounding could obscure marginal duality equivalences; mitigation via exact algebraic computation where feasible.
Published IIA/IIB dual-pair literature is incomplete and may be biased toward well-studied families, limiting validation ground truth.
experiment.requires_followup: Once computational duality orbits are established, a full phenomenological validation would require: (1) perturbative flux quantization and superpotential analysis for predicted IIA/IIB pairs (semi-computational, ~2–3 weeks); (2) low-energy spectrum matching (4D effective Lagrangian comparison between duality partners) to confirm that superstring coupling constants and masses are identical (wet-lab equivalent: compute 4D N=1 supergravity potentials numerically for predicted pairs and verify matching to <1% accuracy). This is still primarily computational but involves symbolic algebra (Macaulay2 or Singular) for superpotential computation.

hypotheses.source_question: How do the geometric constraints and moduli structure of Calabi-Yau fourfolds determine the effective four-dimensional physics of F-theory compactified on these spaces, and conversely, what geometric properties must a Calabi-Yau fourfold possess to realize a given low-energy supersymmetric effective theory?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the geometric singularity structure and fiber topology of Calabi-Yau fourfolds causally constrains the space of realizable four-dimensional N=1 supersymmetric effective theories by enforcing non-trivial relations between the Kähler moduli, superpotential coefficients, and gauge group representations that are invisible in type IIA/IIB threefold compactifications, resulting in a measurable reduction in the cardinality of consistent 4D vacua and the emergence of new swampland criteria.
hypotheses.mechanism: F-theory compactification on a fourfold Y4 induces a singular elliptic fibration whose monodromy, singularity type (Kodira classification), and discriminant locus structure determine the 6D N=1 effective action via Weierstrass model coefficients and resolved geometry. Upon dimensional reduction to 4D via type IIA/IIB duality, the fourfold's Hodge numbers and intersection form impose rigidity constraints on the 4D moduli space that forbid certain combinations of gauge groups, matter spectra, and Yukawa couplings that would naively be allowed in a standalone threefold compactification. This causal flow is: fourfold geometry determines 6D data (matter, gauge, superpotential), which determines 4D low-energy limit, with the fourfold structure acting as a regulating upstream constraint.
hypotheses.prediction: For a fixed 4D effective theory T (defined by gauge group G, matter spectrum, and Yukawa structure), the fraction of Calabi-Yau fourfolds in the extended Kreuzer-Skarke database that can realize T is at least 40 percent smaller than the fraction of threefolds that can realize T; equivalently, at least 30 percent of naively consistent 4D N=1 theories consistent with one-loop anomaly cancellation will admit zero fourfold realizations while admitting one or more threefold realization, as measured by systematic enumeration of both databases and machine-learned fiber-to-EFT maps.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the fraction of fourfold realizations for a given 4D theory T equals (within 5 percent) the fraction of threefold realizations (fourfolds impose no additional geometric constraint), or if greater than 50 percent of 4D theories admitted by threefolds are also admitted by fourfolds in equal measure, the hypothesis is refuted. This would indicate that fourfold geometry is orthogonal to 4D physics rather than causally constraining it.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: At least 30 percent of anomaly-free 4D theories realizable by at least one threefold admit zero fourfold realizations (measured as exact non-existence in extended Kreuzer-Skarke plus ML-screened geometry database). Alternatively: correlation between fourfold geometric invariants (Hodge numbers, singularity type, fiber genus) and 4D EFT data (gauge rank, matter multiplicity) exhibits R-squared greater than 0.25 for multivariate linear model, compared to R-squared less than 0.10 for threefold to 4D correlations.

experiment.approach: Construct a systematic pipeline: (1) generate curated set of explicit Calabi-Yau fourfolds (hypersurfaces, complete intersections) with fully resolved Weierstrass models; (2) compute their 6D N=1 effective data (gauge groups, matter representations, superpotential structure) via toric geometry and singularity analysis; (3) perform dimensional reduction to 4D using type IIA/IIB duality rules; (4) extract 4D invariants (Kähler moduli space, anomaly constraints, Yukawa structure); (5) query Kreuzer-Skarke threefold database for theories realizing the same 4D data; (6) apply machine learning to learn the fourfold-geometry-to-4D-EFT map; (7) measure cardinality reduction and statistical association strength.
steps: Assemble curated library of at least 500 Calabi-Yau fourfolds from Kreuzer-Skarke extended fourfold data, Batyrev hypersurfaces in weighted projective space, and Schutt-Shioda fiber data; verify they satisfy CY conditions (c1=0, Hodge numbers).

For each fourfold, compute Weierstrass model (a and b coefficients as sections of line bundles) and classify singular fibers via Kodira type and monodromy action; extract singularity types (I_n, II, III, IV, etc.) and their multiplicities along discriminant locus.

Use toric and resolution geometry to compute 6D matter content: matter representations from resolved singularities, gauge groups from Dynkin diagrams encoded in fiber singularities, and non-Abelian and Abelian factors via blowup structure.

Compute 6D superpotential structure (cubic couplings from resolved geometry and Yukawa data from matter curves) and apply F-theory and type IIB duality rules to extract 4D N=1 superpotential and Kähler potential after reduction on K3 fiber.

Extract from each fourfold to 4D reduction: 4D gauge group and rank, matter spectrum (multiplicities of matter representations), Yukawa coupling structure (which trilinear couplings are allowed or forbidden by geometry), and Kähler moduli space dimension.

Query Kreuzer-Skarke threefold database (475k or more examples) using extracted 4D data as signature: count how many threefolds realize the same 4D physics (same gauge group, matter content, and anomaly-free conditions).

For each of 500 or more fourfolds, record: realized 4D effective theory, fourfold geometric invariants (Hodge h11 and h12, singularity multiset, discriminant divisor class, fiber genus, monodromy group), number of threefold realizations of same 4D theory, and whether that 4D theory is realizable by any threefold.

Train supervised ML models (gradient boosting on XGBoost or neural network with feature importance) to predict 4D EFT properties (gauge rank, matter multiplicity, Yukawa structure) from fourfold geometric features; measure R-squared on held-out fourfold test set and compare to null model.

Compute fraction of 4D theories (defined by G, matter, Yukawa constraints) realizable exclusively by fourfolds, exclusively by threefolds, and by both; test whether fourfold-exclusive theories form statistically significant subset using chi-squared goodness-of-fit test.

Identify emergent swampland criteria by checking which combinations of 4D invariants (gauge rank plus number of singlets, Kähler moduli dimension) are forbidden in fourfold realizations but allowed in threefolds; use logistic regression to learn binary classifier and extract decision boundary as candidate swampland rule.
tools: SINGULAR or Macaulay2 for algebraic geometry, Gröbner bases, singularity analysis, and resolution of singularities
Sage and SageMath for toric geometry, Calabi-Yau Hodge number computation, and intersection theory
Polymake or palp for toric polytope enumeration and Kreuzer-Skarke database queries

Custom Python scripts for parsing and integrating Kreuzer-Skarke threefold and fourfold databases, 6D to 4D dimensional reduction via Weierstrass model, and Yukawa coupling extraction from resolved geometry
XGBoost, scikit-learn, and TensorFlow/Keras for supervised learning and feature importance analysis
Jupyter notebooks for data wrangling, exploratory analysis, and visualization
arXiv and INSPIRE preprints on F-theory, Weierstrass models, and dimensional reduction
Existing fourfold geometry data from Schutt elliptic fibrations, Batyrev-Borisov mirror pairs, and Hodge diamond searches
experiment.estimated_effort: 8 to 12 weeks compute plus analysis. Database curation and singularity computation 2 weeks; 6D effective action via Weierstrass model 2 weeks; dimensional reduction pipeline 2 weeks; Kreuzer-Skarke matching and threefold query 1 week (parallel); ML training and interpretation 2 weeks; statistical testing and swampland criterion extraction 1 week. GPU cluster (4 or more nodes) for parallel geometry computation and ML training.
experiment.data_requirements: Calabi-Yau fourfold database (extended Kreuzer-Skarke, Batyrev polytopes, or Schutt fiber data with 500 or more explicit examples); Kreuzer-Skarke threefold database (475k or more examples, publicly available); Weierstrass model coefficients and resolution data (custom computation or literature); singularity and monodromy group tables (Kodira classification, Dynkin diagrams); anomaly polynomial reference data (standard from supergravity literature). Total data size 10 to 50 GB manageable on single workstation with SSD.
experiment.expected_positive: Machine-learned feature importances reveal that fourfold geometric invariants (singularity type distribution, Hodge h11, fiber genus) explain at least 25 percent of variance in 4D gauge rank and matter multiplicity (R-squared greater than 0.25), significantly outperforming null model (R-squared less than 0.10). At least 30 percent of naively anomaly-free 4D N=1 theories are realizable by one or more threefold but zero fourfolds. Logistic classifier trained on fourfold versus threefold geometry achieves at least 75 percent balanced accuracy, with decision boundary revealing new swampland constraint (rank of G4D plus n_singlets less than or equal to dimension of Kähler moduli is violated in fourfold realizations but not threefold).
experiment.expected_negative: Fraction of 4D theories realizable by fourfolds equals (within 5 percent) the fraction realizable by threefolds; ML model R-squared less than 0.12 (no better than baseline); greater than 80 percent of 4D theories realizable by threefolds are also realizable by fourfolds in equal proportions. Logistic classifier achieves 55 percent or less balanced accuracy, indicating fourfold and threefold geometry impose orthogonal constraints and are not causally linked in determining 4D physics.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H0: Calabi-Yau fourfold geometry imposes no additional constraint on the space of realizable 4D N=1 effective theories beyond those already imposed by type IIA and IIB threefold compactifications. For any 4D effective theory T, P(T realizable by fourfold given T realizable by threefold) equals P(T realizable by fourfold), meaning fourfold realizability is independent of threefold realizability.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-proportion chi-squared test comparing fraction of fourfold-realizable versus threefold-realizable 4D theories in enumerated sample (n approximately 500 fourfolds and matched 4D data from at least 10k threefolds), alpha equals 0.05 (two-sided). For ML model evaluation: Pearson correlation R between predicted and actual 4D EFT properties, with critical threshold R greater than 0.50 (R-squared greater than 0.25) as evidence of causality; null is R less than 0.32 (R-squared less than 0.10). For logistic classifier: report AUC-ROC at least 0.70 as evidence of discriminative power; null is AUC approximately 0.50.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: At least 25 percent absolute difference in fraction of 4D theories realizable exclusively by fourfolds versus threefolds (for example, 15 percent fourfold-exclusive versus 40 percent threefold-exclusive), detectable with n equals 500 fourfolds and matched threefold sample size n equals 10k (power at least 80 percent, alpha equals 0.05, two-proportion test). Alternatively: R-squared greater than 0.25 for multivariate model predicting 4D EFT from fourfold geometry, corresponding to medium effect size; null R-squared less than 0.10 (small effect). For swampland criterion: new constraint must reduce cardinality of consistent 4D theories by at least 20 percent compared to anomaly-cancellation alone.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Primary test: chi-squared goodness-of-fit for proportions. With n_fourfold approximately 500 and n_threefold approximately 10000 matched samples, we can detect 25 percent absolute difference in theory realization rates with power at least 0.80 and alpha equals 0.05 (two-sided). Secondary test: Pearson r for ML feature importance. To detect R-squared greater than 0.25 (r greater than 0.50) with n approximately 500 fourfold samples and 10 or more 4D EFT properties, power at least 0.90 at alpha equals 0.05. Tertiary test: logistic classifier AUC at least 0.70 with ROC bootstrap CI [0.65, 0.75] at n equals 500, alpha equals 0.05. Convergence criterion (computational): ML models (XGBoost, neural net) trained until validation loss plateaus for 5 consecutive epochs or less than 0.1 percent relative improvement in cross-validation error.
limitations: Database completeness: Kreuzer-Skarke fourfold data is not as extensively catalogued as threefold database; we are restricted to explicitly constructed examples (hypersurfaces, complete intersections, toric hypersurfaces). Mitigation: use multiple fourfold sources (Batyrev, Schutt, newly derived) to cross-validate findings.

Weierstrass model ambiguity: not all fourfolds admit unique Weierstrass model; multiple models may correspond to same underlying geometry. Mitigation: compute j-invariant and discriminant locus for each model to ensure uniqueness up to isomorphism.

Dimensional reduction non-uniqueness: type IIA and IIB duality map from 6D to 4D involves choice of K3 fiber and divisor classes; different choices may yield different 4D data. Mitigation: compute multiple reductions per fourfold and verify consistency; use most generic reduction.

Machine learning interpretability: correlation discovered by ML does not prove causality; strong R-squared could be confounded by common dependence on third variable. Mitigation: perform ablation studies on fourfold features; test for indirect causal pathways via mediation analysis.

Threefold database query bottleneck: matching 4D theory extracted from fourfold to Kreuzer-Skarke threefold database requires solving inverse problem. Mitigation: use approximate matching via machine learning learned embeddings and nearest-neighbor search.

Swampland criterion validation: any new swampland criterion discovered must be checked against independent fourfold and threefold examples not in training set, and ideally against explicit string-theoretic calculations to rule out spurious correlations.

Moduli space stability: dimensional reduction assumes the 4D moduli space is stable and the K3 fiber is generic; singular K3 fibers may give different results. Mitigation: restrict analysis to fourfolds with generic K3 fibers and perform sensitivity analysis.
experiment.requires_followup: Explicit string-theoretic verification: construct 2-3 fourfold examples where the hypothesis predicts forbidden 4D theories and perform detailed flux compactification calculations in F-theory to confirm that the predicted 4D physics is indeed unrealizable. Additionally, perform independent type IIA/IIB mirror symmetry calculations on corresponding threefolds to verify that the same 4D theories are realizable in threefold language. This wet-lab equivalent would definitively establish the causal relationship between fourfold geometry and 4D EFT constraints.

hypotheses.source_question: Why does string theory naturally produce exactly three generations of fermions, and what string-theoretic mechanism determines both the number and the hierarchical mass structure of quark and lepton families?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the number of light fermion generations in string theory is causally determined by the rank of the chiral homology group H¹(C, 𝒪_C) of matter curves in F-theory compactifications, such that generation multiplicity equals the dimension of this cohomology space plus a fixed offset correction from non-Abelian gauge structure.
hypotheses.mechanism: F-theory compactifications define matter curves as the loci where the elliptic fibration discriminant meets the base surface. Chiral fermions localize to these curves, and their replication is governed by the zero-mode structure: the number of chiral multiplets in a given representation is proportional to h¹(C, 𝒪_C) + χ_gauge, where χ_gauge accounts for monodromy and bundle topology on the curve. Three generations arises when h¹(C, 𝒪_C) ≈ 2–3 for the dominant matter curve, combined with gauge-theoretic enhancements. Varying the base geometry and bundle structure causally shifts generation number by modulating this cohomological dimension.
hypotheses.prediction: In a scan of 1000+ F-theory base geometries with explicit matter curve definitions, the generation number of the lightest fermion family will correlate with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) with Pearson's r > 0.75 and median absolute error (MAE) ≤ 0.8 generations. Specifically, 80% of models with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) ∈ [2, 4] will predict 2–4 generations; models with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) < 1 will predict ≤ 1 generation in >90% of cases.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If a computational scan of ≥500 F-theory models finds that h¹(C, 𝒪_C) explains < 50% of variance in generation number (R² < 0.5), or if the correlation coefficient r < 0.6, or if models with identical h¹(C, 𝒪_C) values show generation counts differing by > 2 in > 30% of cases, the hypothesis is refuted. Alternatively, if the offset χ_gauge cannot be consistently defined across gauge groups (SU(5), SO(10), E₆) to within ±1 generation, the mechanism is falsified.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Pearson's r ≥ 0.75 between h¹(C, 𝒪_C) and predicted generation number; R² ≥ 0.56 (56% explained variance); median absolute error ≤ 0.8 generations across a diverse sample of base geometries and gauge structures.

experiment.approach: Systematically compute the geometric invariant h¹(C, 𝒪_C) for matter curves in F-theory base surfaces drawn from published databases (e.g., Kreuzer–Skarke, Weigand et al. surveys). Correlate these cohomological dimensions with the predicted number of light generations extracted from the same literature or computed via standard F-theory uplift formulas. Use regression and machine learning to test whether cohomology rank explains generation multiplicity better than baseline features (Euler characteristic, base surface degree, number of divisors).
steps: Step 1: Curate a dataset of ≥1000 F-theory base surfaces from published compactification studies (Weigand, Mayrhofer, Vafa, and co-workers' surveys, arXiv repositories). For each, extract or compute the explicit matter curves associated with the dominant matter representations (typically 10 and 5̄ in SU(5) or analogues in SO(10), E₆).

Step 2: For each matter curve C, compute h⁰(C, 𝒪_C) (always 1), h¹(C, 𝒪_C), and the arithmetic genus g(C) = 1 + h¹(C, 𝒪_C). Use standard algebraic geometry algorithms (Riemann-Roch theorem applied to curves on the base surface) or obtain from fiber-by-fiber analysis in existing literature.

Step 3: Extract or infer the predicted number of generations from: (a) explicit statements in papers; (b) dimensional analysis of chiral zero mode spaces from brane/curve wrapping; (c) direct computation via the Atiyah-Singer index theorem applied to gauge bundles on matter curves.

Step 4: Compute χ_gauge (bundle/monodromy correction) for each model using established F-theory tools (Weigand-Vafa formalism, codimension-two enhancement rules). This accounts for additional chiral multiplets from non-Abelian gauge structure.
Step 5: Perform multivariate regression: generation number ~ h¹(C, 𝒪_C) + χ_gauge + interaction terms. Compute R², Pearson's r, MAE. Test fit quality separately for SU(5), SO(10), E₆ gauge groups.
Step 6: Scan ±50% perturbations in base geometry (blowups, divisor moves, fiber modulations) and verify that predicted generation number shifts monotonically with h¹(C, 𝒪_C). Document sensitivity.

Step 7: Use gradient boosting (XGBoost, SHAP) to rank feature importance: does h¹(C, 𝒪_C) rank in top 3 predictors of generation number? Does it outrank baseline geometry measures (Euler number, dimension)?
Step 8: Perform ablation test: fit model with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) alone, then with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) + χ_gauge, and compare AIC/BIC to null (constant generation number). Verify Δ(AIC) > 10 (strong evidence).
tools: SINGULAR/Macaulay2 (algebraic geometry; cohomology computation)
Kreuzer–Skarke database (K3-fibered base surfaces)
Published F-theory compactification datasets (Weigand et al., Mayrhofer et al., arXiv 1408.4808, 1609.04408, 1701.05174)
Python scikit-learn / XGBoost (regression, feature ranking)
Custom F-theory toolkit (e.g., based on Weigand's group libraries or publicly available scripts for matter curve identification)
Mathematica/Wolfram Language (index calculations, Riemann-Roch automation)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks. Weeks 1–2: dataset curation and literature mining. Weeks 3–4: automated cohomology computation pipeline development and validation on 100 test cases. Weeks 5–7: batch computation of h¹(C, 𝒪_C) for 1000+ models and cross-check against literature. Weeks 8–10: multivariate regression, sensitivity analysis, and SHAP feature analysis. Weeks 11–12: validation, writing, and documentation.
experiment.data_requirements: Access to (1) published F-theory base surface geometries and matter curve specifications (available in arXiv and research group repositories); (2) computational algebra systems (SINGULAR, Macaulay2 are open-source); (3) generation number predictions from literature or recomputable via standard F-theory formulas; (4) modest compute: ~100 CPU-hours for full dataset (parallelizable).
experiment.expected_positive: A scatter plot and regression fit showing generation number vs. h¹(C, 𝒪_C) with r > 0.75 and R² > 0.56. SHAP analysis ranks h¹(C, 𝒪_C) as the dominant feature. Models with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) ∈ [2, 4] predominantly predict 2–4 generations; h¹(C, 𝒪_C) < 1 predicts ≤ 1 generation in >90% of cases. Residuals are random (no systematic bias by gauge group). Sensitivity analysis shows monotonic generation shifts with h¹(C, 𝒪_C) perturbations.
experiment.expected_negative: Correlation r < 0.6, or R² < 0.5; h¹(C, 𝒪_C) ranked outside top-5 features by SHAP; or generation counts vary by >2 across models with identical h¹(C, 𝒪_C) in >30% of cases. Alternatively, χ_gauge cannot be consistently defined (varies unpredictably across models), or residuals show strong dependence on gauge group (indicating the mechanism is gauge-dependent, not fundamental).
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Generation number is statistically independent of h¹(C, 𝒪_C) (correlation coefficient ρ = 0, R² = 0). Equivalently: generation number is determined by factors unrelated to matter curve cohomology (e.g., random landscaping, anthropic selection alone, or flux-dependent dynamics that decouple from geometry).
experiment.statistical_test: Multivariate linear regression with F-test for model fit (H₀: all coefficients = 0, α = 0.01). Secondary: Spearman's rank correlation ρ (two-tailed, α = 0.01) as a non-parametric robustness check. Tertiary: Akaike Information Criterion (AIC) comparison of full model vs. null model (Δ(AIC) > 10 = strong evidence). SHAP feature importance ranking with 95% confidence intervals.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Pearson's r ≥ 0.75 (corresponding to R² ≈ 0.56, a medium–large effect in population studies); median absolute error ≤ 0.8 generations; F-statistic > 25 (p < 0.001) for the full regression model with n ≈ 1000. In feature importance: h¹(C, 𝒪_C) + χ_gauge must account for >50% of total SHAP value magnitude across the dataset.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: With n ≈ 1000 F-theory models, a two-tailed correlation test achieves >99% power to detect r ≥ 0.75 at α = 0.01. Regression analysis with 2–3 predictors (h¹, χ_gauge, interaction) on 1000 observations yields standard errors < 0.15 for main effects, ensuring precision. For computational experiments, convergence criterion: generation predictions agree to ±0.5 generations between independent literature sources for ≥95% of the 1000-model subset (cross-validation). No multiple comparison correction needed: single primary hypothesis (h¹ vs. generation number).
limitations: Literature extraction bias: generation numbers and matter curve definitions in published papers may be incomplete or inconsistent across studies. Mitigation: cross-reference ≥2 independent sources per model; flag uncertain cases.

Geometric computation assumes explicit base surface descriptions are available or computable; obscure geometries may be under-represented. Mitigation: focus on well-studied families (K3-fibered bases, del Pezzo families).

χ_gauge (bundle correction) is sensitive to monodromy and enhancement rules; these may be model-dependent or not fully catalogued. Mitigation: systematically apply Weigand-Vafa formalism; document divergences.
Generation number from literature is sometimes quoted without derivation. Mitigation: recompute via index theorem wherever possible; validate on a 100-model subset against cited values.

Causality: correlation does not prove that h¹(C, 𝒪_C) mechanistically *causes* generation number. Perturbation analysis (Step 6) partially addresses this by showing directional sensitivity, but true causality requires wet-lab validation (see requires_followup).

Three-generation bias: the dataset may preferentially include models with 3 generations because the literature focuses on Standard Model-like vacua. Mitigation: actively seek and include non-3-generation models from the literature (e.g., models with 1–2 or 4+ generations).
experiment.requires_followup: This experiment is entirely computational and derives testable predictions from existing F-theory literature. However, to fully confirm causality and rule out confounding, a follow-up wet-lab/phenomenological study would involve: (1) constructing explicit D-brane or heterotic string models in the landscape that realize the predicted h¹(C, 𝒪_C)–generation correlations; (2) computing Yukawa coupling matrices from worldsheet instantons for high-h¹ and low-h¹ models to verify that only high-h¹ models produce realistic mass hierarchies and mixing angles; (3) performing a global landscape scan (e.g., via heterotic–Type II duality or F-theory on higher-genus fibrations) to assess whether three-generation vacua are dynamically preferred (e.g., via moduli stabilization or swampland constraints). These follow-ups would transition from correlation to mechanistic proof.

hypotheses.source_question: How do the geometric and combinatorial properties of reflexive polytopes in arbitrary dimension constrain or enable the construction of smooth Calabi-Yau hypersurfaces, and can dimension-independent invariants predict which reflexive polytopes yield geometrically favorable string landscape vacua?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that dimension-independent combinatorial invariants of reflexive polytopes—specifically, the normalized lattice point density, Gorenstein index, and face lattice depth—causally constrain the Hodge numbers (h¹¹) and singularity genus of associated Calabi-Yau hypersurfaces, enabling predictive screening of polytopes for string phenomenology relevance without explicit geometric computation.
hypotheses.mechanism: Reflexivity imposes a duality constraint on the lattice point distribution of a polytope P and its polar dual P*. As dimension increases, this constraint couples the combinatorial structure (face enumeration, lattice sparsity) to the algebraic geometry of the hypersurface it defines via toric geometry: the Hodge diamond is determined by the Stanley-Reisner ring, which is encoded in the face lattice. Higher Gorenstein index and normalized lattice density proxy for more singular/degenerate toric hypersurfaces; face lattice depth controls the complexity of the resolution of singularities. We propose that these three invariants jointly predict h¹¹ via a learned regression mapping that generalizes across dimensions d ≥ 3.
hypotheses.prediction: A machine learning model trained on polytope invariants (lattice density, Gorenstein index, face lattice depth) extracted from >5000 reflexive polytopes in dimensions 3–6 will predict the Hodge number h¹¹ of the associated smooth Calabi-Yau hypersurface with mean absolute error (MAE) < 3 on a held-out test set (n=1000 polytopes), outperforming a baseline linear regression by at least 40% in MAE. Furthermore, the model will correctly classify polytopes into 'phenomenologically viable' (h¹¹ ≤ 10) vs. 'generic' (h¹¹ > 10) categories with F1-score ≥ 0.75.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If the trained model achieves MAE ≥ 5 on test polytopes in any single dimension (d ≥ 4), or F1-score < 0.60 for the viability classification, the hypothesis is falsified. Alternatively, if invariants show zero correlation (Spearman ρ < 0.15) with h¹¹ in the full dataset, the causal claim is rejected. A third falsifying result: if dimension-d invariants do not transfer across dimensions (e.g., a model trained on d=4 polytopes scores F1 < 0.50 on d=5 test set), the dimension-independence claim fails.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Mean absolute error in h¹¹ prediction < 3 (compared to observed range ~1–50); Spearman correlation between any single invariant and h¹¹ ≥ 0.40; cross-dimensional model transferability (same model, trained on 50% mixed-dimension data, achieving F1 ≥ 0.68 on held-out d=5,6 polytopes); classifier precision ≥ 0.75 for 'phenomenologically viable' class.

experiment.approach: Systematically compute combinatorial invariants for all reflexive polytopes in dimensions 3–6 from public databases, compute or retrieve Hodge numbers for their associated smooth hypersurfaces using established toric methods, then train a supervised ensemble model (gradient boosted trees) to predict h¹¹ from polytope invariants. Validate predictive power and cross-dimensional generalization on held-out test sets and compare against a dimension-agnostic baseline.
steps: Step 1: Retrieve or generate complete or near-complete list of reflexive polytopes in dimensions d=3,4,5,6 from the Kreuzer–Skarke database and computational geometry libraries (e.g., Polymake, SageMath). For d=4, use existing enumeration (~500K polytopes); for d=5,6, sample or compute ~5K–10K each via systematic methods (e.g., degree/volume bounded search).

Step 2: For each polytope P, compute and extract five key combinatorial invariants: (a) normalized lattice point density = (# interior + boundary lattice points) / volume; (b) Gorenstein index g(P) = min{k : kP is Gorenstein}; (c) face lattice depth = max length of chains in the Hasse diagram; (d) number of facets; (e) volume (normalized by dimension). Use Polymake or SageMath for fast computation.

Step 3: For each polytope, compute or retrieve the Hodge numbers (h¹¹, h¹² if complete intersection) of the associated smooth Calabi-Yau hypersurface using toric methods (Stanley-Reisner ring cohomology, or pre-computed databases for d=4). For d≥5, focus on anticanonical or Fano hypersurfaces where Hodge computation is tractable; use CY database queries or compute via toric resolution (e.g., via Sage or Oscar).

Step 4: Split data into train (70%), validation (10%), test (20%) sets, stratifying by dimension to ensure each set spans d=3–6 uniformly. Train multiple supervised models: (i) gradient boosted regression (XGBoost/LightGBM) to predict h¹¹ as continuous target; (ii) logistic regression to classify polytopes as 'viable' (h¹¹ ≤ 10) vs. generic.

Step 5: For regression model: report test-set MAE, R², and Spearman correlation with true h¹¹. For classifier: report precision, recall, F1, and AUC-ROC on test set. Compute feature importance (SHAP values) to identify which invariants drive predictions.

Step 6: Test cross-dimensional transfer: train on mixed d=3,4 data; evaluate on held-out d=5,6 test sets. If transfer is poor, train separate dimension-specific models and test whether coefficients/patterns generalize.

Step 7: Perform ablation analysis: remove one invariant at a time and retrain; compare MAE/F1 drop to quantify each invariant's contribution. If one invariant (e.g., Gorenstein index) dominates, re-examine the hypothesis mechanism.

Step 8: Explicitly validate predictions on a small held-out set (n=50) of polytopes by computing Hodge numbers via independent toric or algebraic geometry software (Oscar, Macaulay2) and comparing to model predictions.
tools: Polymake (polytope enumeration and invariant computation)
SageMath (toric geometry, Hodge number calculation, Stanley-Reisner rings)
Kreuzer–Skarke database (4D reflexive polyhedra enumeration and pre-computed Hodge numbers)
XGBoost or LightGBM (gradient boosted tree training)
Python (Pandas, Scikit-learn for train/test split, feature engineering, SHAP for interpretability)
Oscar (Julia-based computer algebra; alternative for independent Hodge validation)
CY database / PolyDB (optional: pre-computed Hodge numbers for cross-reference)
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks compute + analysis. Polytope enumeration (d=5,6): 2–3 weeks on parallel cluster (~100 cores); Hodge number retrieval/computation: 2–3 weeks; feature extraction: 1 week; model training & validation: 2 weeks; cross-validation & interpretability analysis: 2 weeks; write-up & reproducible pipeline: 1 week.
experiment.data_requirements: Complete or representative sample of reflexive polytopes in d=3–6 (estimated: 1M total after sampling); pre-computed or computable Hodge numbers for anticanonical/complete intersection hypersurfaces; computational resources: ~100 CPU-cores or GPU cluster for parallel enumeration; storage: ~50 GB for polytope data, invariants, and model checkpoints.
experiment.expected_positive: Model achieves MAE < 3 on test set h¹¹ predictions (e.g., predicting polytopes with true h¹¹ = 5 to within ±3 on average). Classifier correctly identifies viable polytopes with F1 ≥ 0.75. Feature importance analysis shows Gorenstein index and lattice density as top 2 predictors. Cross-dimensional transfer achieves F1 ≥ 0.68. Spearman correlations between invariants and h¹¹ all > 0.35.
experiment.expected_negative: MAE ≥ 5 or F1 < 0.60. Invariants show Spearman ρ < 0.15 with h¹¹ (no signal). Cross-dimensional transfer fails (F1 < 0.50 on d=5,6 test). Feature importance is uniform across invariants (all ≤ 5% gain), suggesting no dominant causal structure. Explicit toric validation on 50 polytopes shows predicted h¹¹ systematically off by >5 for >30% of samples.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: Reflexive polytope invariants (Gorenstein index, lattice density, face lattice depth) have no predictive power for Hodge numbers; h¹¹ is determined by higher-order or non-local geometric properties not encoded in these combinatorial summaries. Equivalently, h¹¹ is independent (ρ = 0) of all three invariants.
experiment.statistical_test: Two-stage testing: (1) Spearman rank-order correlation test between each invariant and h¹¹ across full dataset; H₀: ρ = 0, α = 0.05, Bonferroni-corrected for multiple invariants. (2) Cross-validation: 5-fold CV on training set; compare test-set MAE of trained model vs. null baseline (predicting h¹¹ mean). Reject H₀ if test MAE is lower by ≥40% (paired t-test, α = 0.05). (3) Classification F1 test: exact binomial test for classifier precision ≥ 0.75 (α = 0.05).
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Spearman correlation ≥ 0.40 between any single invariant and h¹¹ (n > 5000 polytopes, power = 0.95 to detect; smallest correlation ρ = 0.04 is statistically significant but too small for practical prediction). For MAE: 40% reduction from baseline (e.g., baseline MAE = 8 → model MAE = 4.8) on n = 1000 test polytopes. For classification: precision ≥ 0.75 (two-sided 95% binomial confidence interval excludes 0.50).
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Dataset size: n_train ≈ 3500 polytopes (across d=3–6); n_test = 1000; n_val = 500. Assumed effect size: moderate (Spearman ρ ≈ 0.45–0.60 for Gorenstein index vs. h¹¹ based on prior 4D work). With n=3500 train, power to detect ρ > 0.40 is >0.99. For MAE comparison (paired t-test on 1000 test predictions): assumed Cohen's d ≈ 0.50 (40% reduction in SD); power = 0.90 with n=1000. Model convergence: use early stopping on validation set (patience=20 rounds); report final train/val/test loss and AUC.
limitations: Hodge number computation for d≥5 is challenging and may rely on pre-computed databases or approximations; explicit validation limited to d=4 where computations are fastest.
Reflexive polytopes in d≥5 are incompletely enumerated; results apply only to sampled or bounded sub-families, limiting generalizability claims.
Invariants (Gorenstein index, face lattice depth) may be correlated; multicollinearity could inflate feature importance of proxy variables rather than true causal drivers.
Machine learning model interpretability: while SHAP can rank features, it does not reveal the functional form of the causal relationship (e.g., is h¹¹ ∝ Gorenstein index or nonlinear?).
Causality claim is associational, not mechanistic: model may identify useful predictors without proving they directly determine Hodge numbers.
Transfer learning across dimensions assumes polytope geometry follows universal principles; if dimension-specific effects are large, cross-dimensional predictions may fail.
experiment.requires_followup: Yes: To confirm causal mechanism, follow up with explicit toric geometry computation (using Oscar, Macaulay2, or Singular) on a curated subset of predicted-viable polytopes (n ≈ 20–50 per dimension). This wet-lab-equivalent step verifies that Hodge numbers and singularity structure match model predictions and checks for false positives. Additionally, construct a geometrically explicit string phenomenology pipeline (moduli counting, gauge coupling unification) on 5–10 predicted-viable polytopes from d=5,6 to validate that machine-predicted 'viable' polytopes actually yield phenomenologically realistic vacua. If successful, this would justify building a queryable oracle database.

hypotheses.source_question: How do the categorical and geometric properties of Calabi-Yau varieties (as algebraic objects) constrain or enable the physical consistency and moduli structure of string compactifications, compared to treatments that invoke Calabi-Yau manifolds purely as smooth geometric targets?
hypotheses.statement: We hypothesize that the singularity type and algebraic-geometric invariants of a Calabi-Yau variety (specifically: log-canonical threshold, discrepancy, and derived category generators) causally determine the dimension and structure of the string theory moduli space, such that varieties with identical smooth deformation types but different singular resolutions yield inequivalent physical consistency constraints and enhanced gauge symmetries.
hypotheses.mechanism: Singularities in Calabi-Yau varieties act as algebraic-geometric 'anchorpoints' for D-brane categories and exceptional collections. The derived category of coherent sheaves, controlled by singularity invariants, directly constrains which moduli fields remain massless after string compactification. Specifically: (1) singularities with higher log-canonical threshold (LCT) permit fewer geometric deformations, reducing moduli dimension; (2) non-trivial Chow group generators encode non-geometric fluxes that stabilize moduli; (3) exceptional collections in the derived category lift to enhanced gauge groups via Sen limits. Thus: singularity invariants → derived category structure → physical moduli constraints and discrete symmetries.
hypotheses.prediction: For a given topological type of Calabi-Yau threefold, two birational models with different singularity types will differ in their string moduli dimension by at least 5–10 fields (e.g., Kähler + complex structure moduli), and the variety with lower log-canonical threshold will exhibit enhanced non-abelian gauge groups (rank ≥ 3 higher) in the associated string vacua, compared to smooth resolutions of the same topological space.
hypotheses.falsification_criteria: If, for a fixed topological Calabi-Yau type (e.g., a quintic or Fermat family), two distinct singular models with LCT values differing by >0.5 yield identical moduli dimensions (within ±1 field) and identical enhanced gauge groups (same rank and flavor structure) when mapped to string vacua via geometric engineering, the hypothesis is refuted. Alternatively, if smooth resolutions and singular models produce identical moduli spectra regardless of singularity invariant values, the causal link is broken.
hypotheses.minimum_effect_size: Moduli dimension difference ≥ 5 fields between singular and smooth models (measured via Hodge diamond and deformation-obstruction space); gauge group rank enhancement ≥ 3 at singular locus; R² > 0.7 in correlation between log-canonical threshold and moduli dimension across a family of ≥10 singular Calabi-Yau varieties with fixed topology.

experiment.approach: Computationally extract algebraic-geometric invariants (log-canonical threshold, discrepancy, Chow group rank, exceptional collections) from explicit singular Calabi-Yau variety families (e.g., weighted projective spaces, toric hypersurfaces, Landau-Ginzburg orbifolds). Cross-reference invariants with published string theory moduli counts and enhanced symmetries via geometric engineering dictionaries. Construct a predictive model linking singularity invariants to moduli dimension and perform retroactive validation on known string vacua.
steps: Curate a database of ≥15 singular Calabi-Yau threefolds from string compactification literature, sampling across singularity types (A-D-E, F, rational double points, non-normal singularities). Extract topological invariants (Euler characteristic, Hodge numbers) and singularity data.

For each variety, compute (or retrieve from online resources): log-canonical threshold (LCT) via toric methods or resolution of singularities; discrepancy; singular locus dimension and codimension; Chow group rank (if available from LMFDB or Macaulay2).

Compute or extract from literature: derived category generators, exceptional collections, and quiver representations for each singularity type using categorical tools (Bridgeland stability, stability conditions).
For each singular variety, identify its smooth crepant resolution(s) and compute the same invariants; quantify the difference in algebraic-geometric structure.

Cross-reference singularity invariants with string theory moduli-counting results: extract moduli dimensions (Hodge h¹¹, h¹² for Calabi-Yau threefolds) and enhanced gauge groups (via Sen limit, monodromy, heterotic duality) from ≥10 published geometric engineering papers.

Build a regression/correlation matrix: map (LCT, discrepancy, Chow rank, exceptional collection size) → (moduli dimension, gauge group rank). Test for R² > 0.7 and statistical significance (p < 0.05).

For a single well-studied family (e.g., weighted K3 surfaces embedded in Calabi-Yau or conifold-type singularities), construct the singular variety explicitly in Macaulay2 or SageMath, compute invariants numerically, predict moduli/symmetry structure, and validate against known physics literature.

Test falsification: identify two singular models with identical topology but different LCT values; verify whether moduli dimensions differ by ≥5 and gauge enhancements differ (rank ≥ 3). If not, reject hypothesis.
tools: Macaulay2 or SageMath (algebraic geometry computation, singularity resolution, Chow groups)
LMFDB (L-functions and Modular Forms Database) for Calabi-Yau invariants
Bridgeland stability software or quiver algebra packages (derived categories, exceptional collections)
Custom Python/Julia scripts for singularity invariant extraction and correlation analysis
Published string theory compactification tables (arXiv papers 9211001v1, 2506.01068v6, 1412.8000v1, 1305.0594v1, 2303.13502v2, and heterotic/Type II mirror symmetry literature)
Toric geometry tools (Polymake, normaliz) for log-canonical threshold computation via toric resolutions
experiment.estimated_effort: 8–12 weeks: 2–3 weeks database curation + singularity catalog; 3–4 weeks invariant computation (LCT, Chow, categories); 2–3 weeks cross-referencing string physics literature and moduli extraction; 2 weeks statistical analysis and case-study validation.
experiment.data_requirements: Explicit equations or toric fans for ≥15 singular Calabi-Yau threefolds; published moduli dimension and gauge group data from ≥10 string compactification papers; access to Macaulay2/SageMath and LMFDB; derived category literature (quiver and stability data) for singularity types.
experiment.expected_positive: Positive correlation (R² ≥ 0.7, p < 0.05) between log-canonical threshold and moduli dimension; singular models consistently show 5–10 fewer or more moduli fields than smooth resolutions; singularity invariants predict enhanced gauge group rank with ≥80% accuracy on held-out string compactification examples; case-study prediction matches known physics within 1–2 fields and ±1 gauge rank.
experiment.expected_negative: No significant correlation (R² < 0.4, p > 0.05) between singularity invariants and moduli dimension; singular and smooth models yield identical moduli spectra; case-study prediction fails to match known string vacua by >2 fields or gauge rank; exceptional collections show no correlation with enhanced symmetries.
experiment.null_hypothesis: H₀: The singularity type and algebraic-geometric invariants (LCT, discrepancy, Chow rank, derived categories) are statistically independent of the string theory moduli dimension and enhanced gauge group structure. Equivalently: smooth Calabi-Yau manifolds and singular Calabi-Yau varieties with the same topological type impose identical physical constraints on string compactifications.
experiment.statistical_test: Spearman rank correlation test (non-parametric, robust to small sample size and non-linearity) between log-canonical threshold and moduli dimension, with Bonferroni correction for multiple comparisons; two-tailed t-test comparing moduli dimensions of singular vs. smooth models (paired samples, assuming ≥10 pairs), α = 0.05; linear regression R² test for multivariate model (LCT + discrepancy + Chow rank → moduli dim), F-test for model significance.
experiment.minimum_detectable_effect: Moduli dimension change ≥5 between singular and smooth models (effect size: Cohen's d ≥ 1.0, meaningful in geometric context); correlation coefficient |ρ| ≥ 0.6 between singularity invariants and moduli (Spearman, medium effect). For n = 10–15 varieties (small sample), power = 0.80, α = 0.05 (two-tailed), this is achievable; for n = 20+, detectability improves to Cohen's d ≥ 0.6.
experiment.statistical_power_notes: Assumed sample size: n = 15 singular Calabi-Yau varieties with paired smooth resolutions (n = 15 pairs). Assumed effect size: moduli dimension difference of ≥5 fields, σ ≈ 3 (moderate biological variability in geometric families). Two-tailed paired t-test, α = 0.05, desired power = 0.80 yields n ≈ 12–14. For correlation (LCT vs. moduli), ρ = 0.6–0.7 (medium to large geometric effect), n = 15 achieves ~85% power. Convergence criterion for computational steps: singularity invariant algorithms (Macaulay2 resolutions) converge to closed-form Chow groups or numerical approximation with relative error <10⁻⁶; exceptional collection computations via quiver algorithms terminate when stability chamber is fully mapped.
limitations: Database of singular Calabi-Yau varieties may be incomplete or biased toward well-studied cases; selection bias toward varieties with explicitly known string compactifications could obscure causal relationships.
Moduli dimension extraction from literature is indirect; string papers often report Hodge numbers rather than full deformation-obstruction spaces, conflating geometric and physical moduli.
Derived category computations are difficult for high-codimension singularities; exceptional collections are not fully understood for non-ADE cases, limiting scope to 'nice' singularities.
Geometric engineering predictions depend on heterotic/Type II/F-theory duality choices; different duality frames may assign different moduli to the same variety, confounding causal inference.
